description: This course provides an introduction to real estate with a focus on investment and financing issues. Project evaluation, financing strategies, investment decision making and real estate capital markets are covered. No prior knowledge of the industry is required, but students are expected to rapidly acquire a working knowledge of real estate markets. Classes are conducted in a standard lecture format with discussion required. The course contains cases that help students evaluate the impact of more complex financing and capital markets tools used in real estate. There are case studies and two midterms, (depending on instructor).
name: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS

values.comments:
Focusing on investment and financing issues, this course is an introduction to real estate. Finance methods such as project evaluation, financial strategies, investment decision-making, and real estate capital markets are covered. Although an introductory course, students are expected to rapidly acquire a working knowledge of the real estate markets. The course contains many case studies to help the students understand the complex financing and capital market tools used in real estate. 

Overall, many students enjoyed the class and commented it was a “very good introduction” into real estate and students left the class feeling better informed about Real Estate Finance. Furthermore, students got a background in both qualitative and quantitative aspects to real estate. However, some students thought the material was presented poorly and thought only the textbook was helpful. 

The overall assessment of the Professor Bucchianeri was mixed. Some students commented she was “top notch” in her lecture style and one of the most “engaging” and “articulate” teachers they’ve ever had at Penn. However, other students commented she has a thick accent and talked too fast. Furthermore, a few students praised her ability to break down the material to understand, while other students said they had never experienced such random and subjective grading before at Penn. Overall, students believed Professor Bucchiarneri was successful at teaching the real estate concepts, but struggled to teach the financial side. 

A few students recommended this class to all students because of its widely applicable concepts, however it is very finance heavy. Students complained about the incredible amount of work the cases took, but the overall work load for the course was easy to handle. Furthermore, attendance is not taken during this class, which can be helpful for senior students during OCR. However, the biggest complaint for the class was the hard exams, which were graded subjectively and didn’t make much sense.
